p: Salvia (sage) is the largest genus of the Lamiaceae family, which is native of the Mediterranean area and includes about 900 species (Walker et al., 2004[ 55]). From its Latin name “ Salvia”, meaning to cure, it is used in folk medicine for their antibacterial (Özcan et al., 2009[ 40]), antitumoral (Cardile et al., 2009[ 7]), antidiabetic (Kim et al., 2007[ 22]), and antioxidant (Kolak et al., 2009[ 25]) activities. Sage is also used traditionally in food preparation, herbal tea (Demirci et al., 2005[ 11]), flavoring agents in perfumery and cosmetics (Delamare Longaray et al., 2007[ 10]).
